Repeal and savings.3 THE COMMERCIAL COURTS ACT, 2015ACT NO. 4 OF 2016[31st December , 2015.]An Act to provide for the constitution of Commercial Courts, 1[Commercial Appellate Courts,]Commercial Division and Commercial Appellate Division in the High Courts foradjudicating commercial disputes of specified value and matters connected therewith orincidental thereto.BE it enacted by Parliament in the Sixty-sixth Year of the Republic of India as follows:—CHAPTER I

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 1. Short title, extent and commencement. —2[(1) This Act may be called the Commercial CourtsAct, 2015.]

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) It extends to the whole of India except the State of Jammu and Kashmir.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) It shall be deemed to have come into force on the 23rd day of October, 2015.

Definitions. —(1) In this Act, unless the context otherwise requires,––3[(a) “Commercial Appellate Courts” means the Commercial Appellate Courts designated undersection 3A;]4[(aa)] “Commercial Appellate Division” means the Commercial Appellate Division in a HighCourt constituted under sub-section ( 1) of section 5;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) “Commercial Court” means the Commercial Court constituted under sub-section ( 1) ofsection 3;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) “commercial dispute” means a dispute arising out of––

Title: SECTIONS

Title: SECTIONS

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (vii) agreements relating to immovable property used exclusively in trade or commerce;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (viii) franchising agreements;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ix) distribution and licensing agreements;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (x) management and consultancy agreements;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (xi) joint venture agreements;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (xii) shareholders agreements;

Paragraph Text: 4. Clause ( a) renumbered as clause ( aa) by s. 4, ibid., (w.e.f. 3-5-2018).4 (xiii) subscription and investment agreements pertaining to the services industry includingoutsourcing services and financial services;

Paragraph Text: (xiv) mercantile agency and mercantile usage;

Paragraph Text: (xv) partnership agreements;

Constitution of Commercial Courts. —(1) The State Government, may after consultation with theconcerned High Court, by notification, constitute such number of Commercial Courts at District level, asit may deem necessary for the purpose of exercising the jurisdiction and powers conferred on thoseCourts under this Act:2[Provided that with respect to the High Courts having ordinary original civil jurisdiction, the StateGovernment may, after consultation with the concerned High Court, by notification, constituteCommercial Courts at the District Judge level:Provided further that with respect to a territory over which the High Courts have ordinary originalcivil jurisdiction, the State Government may, by notification, specify such pecuniary value which shallnot be less than three lakh rupees and not more than the pecuniary jurisdiction exercisable by the DistrictCourts, as it may consider necessary.]3[(1A) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, the State Government may, after consultationwith the concerned High Court, by notification, specify such pecuniary value which shall not be less thanthree lakh rupees or such higher value, for whole or part of the State, as it may consider necessary.];

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) The State Government shall, after consultation with the concerned High Court specify, bynotification, the local limits of the area to which the jurisdiction of a Commercial Court shall extend andmay, from time to time, increase, reduce or alter such limits.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) The 4[State Government may], with the concurrence of the Chief Justice of the High Court appointone or more persons having experience in dealing with commercial disputes to be the Judge or Judges, ofa 5[Commercial Court either at the level of District Judge or a court below the level of a District Judge].6[3A.Designation of Commercial Appellate Courts .—Except the territories over which the HighCourts have ordinary original civil jurisdiction, the State Government may, after consultation with theconcerned High Court, by notification, designate such number of Commercial Appellate Courts at DistrictJudge level, as it may deem necessary, for the purposes of exercising the jurisdiction and powersconferred on those Courts under this Act.]

Paragraph Text: 4. Constitution of Commercial Division of High Court. —(1) In all High Courts, having 7[ordinaryoriginal civil jurisdiction], the Chief Justice of the High Court may, by order, constitute CommercialDivision having one or more Benches consisting of a single Judge for the purpose of exercising thejurisdiction and powers conferred on it under this Act.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) The Chief Justice of the High Court shall nominate such Judges of the High Court who haveexperience in dealing with commercial disputes to be Judges of the Commercial Division.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 5. Constitution of Commercial Appellate Division. —(1) After issuing notification under sub-section ( 1) of section 3 or order under sub-section ( 1) of section 4, the Chief Justice of the concernedHigh Court shall, by order, constitute Commercial Appellate Division having one or more DivisionBenches for the purpose of exercising the jurisdiction and powers conferred on it by the Act.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) The Chief Justice of the High Court shall nominate such Judges of the High Court who haveexperience in dealing with commercial disputes to be Judges of the Commercial Appellate Division.

Jurisdiction of Commercial Court. —The Commercial Court shall have jurisdiction to try all suitsand applications relating to a commercial dispute of a Specified Value arising out of the entire territory ofthe State over which it has been vested territorial jurisdiction.Explanation .––For the purposes of this section, a commercial dispute shall be considered to arise outof the entire territory of the State over which a Commercial Court has been vested jurisdiction, if the suitor application relating to such commercial dispute has been instituted as per the provisions of sections 16to 20 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908).

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 7. Jurisdiction of Commercial Divisions of High Courts. —All suits and applications relating tocommercial disputes of a Specified Value filed in a High Court having ordinary original civil jurisdictionshall be heard and disposed of by the Commercial Division of that High Court:Provided that all suits and applications relating to commercial disputes, stipulated by an Act to lie in acourt not inferior to a District Court, and filed or pending on the original side of the High Court, shall beheard and disposed of by the Commercial Division of the High Court:Provided further that all suits and applications transferred to the High Court by virtue of sub-section

Title: SECTIONS

Bar against revision application or petition against an interlocutory order. —Notwithstandinganything contained in any other law for the time being in force, no civil revision application or petitionshall be entertained against any interlocutory order of a Commercial Court, including an order on theissue of jurisdiction, and any such challenge, subject to the provisions of section 13, shall be raised onlyin an appeal against the decree of the Commercial Court.

Paragraph Text: 10. Jurisdiction in respect of arbitration matters. —Where the subject-matter of an arbitration is acommercial dispute of a Specified Value and––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (1) If such arbitration is an international commercial arbitration, all applications or appealsarising out of such arbitration under the provisions of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996(26 of 1996) that have been filed in a High Court, shall be heard and disposed of by the CommercialDivision where such Commercial Division has been constituted in such High Court.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) If such arbitration is other than an international commercial arbitration, all applications orappeals arising out of such arbitration under the provisions of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act,1996 (26 of 1996) that have been filed on the original side of the High Court, shall be heard anddisposed of by the Commercial Division where such Commercial Division has been constituted insuch High Court.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) If such arbitration is other than an international commercial arbitration, all applications orappeals arising out of such arbitration under the provisions of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act,1996 (26 of 1996) that would ordinarily lie before any principal civil court of original jurisdiction in adistrict (not being a High Court) shall be filed in, and heard and disposed of by the Commercial Courtexercising territorial jurisdiction over such arbitration where such Commercial Court has beenconstituted.

Paragraph Text: 11. Bar of jurisdiction of Commercial Courts and Commercial Divisions. —Notwithstandinganything contained in this Act, a Commercial Court or a Commercial Division shall not entertain ordecide any suit, application or proceedings relating to any commercial dispute in respect of which thejurisdiction of the civil court is either expressly or impliedly barred under any other law for the time beingin force.7 CHAPTER IIISPECIFIED  VALUE

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 12. Determination of Specified Value. —(1) The Specified Value of the subject-matter of thecommercial dispute in a suit, appeal or application shall be determined in the following manner:––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) where the relief sought in a suit or application is for recovery of money, the money sought tobe recovered in the suit or application inclusive of interest, if any, computed up to the date of filing ofthe suit or application, as the case may be, shall be taken into account for determining such SpecifiedValue;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) where the relief sought in a suit, appeal or application relates to movable property or to a righttherein, the market value of the movable property as on the date of filing of the suit, appeal orapplication, as the case may be, shall be taken into account for determining such Specified Value;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) where the relief sought in a suit, appeal or application relates to immovable property or to aright therein, the market value of the immovable property, as on the date of filing of the suit, appealor application, as the case may be, shall be taken into account for determining Specified Value; 1[and]

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) where the relief sought in a suit, appeal or application relates to any other intangible right, themarket value of the said rights as estimated by the plaintiff shall be taken into account fordetermining Specified Value; 2* * *3* * * * *

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) The aggregate value of the claim and counterclaim, if any as set out in the statement of claim andthe counterclaim, if any, in an arbitration of a commercial dispute shall be the basis for determiningwhether such arbitration is subject to the jurisdiction of a Commercial Division, Commercial AppellateDivision or Commercial Court, as the case may be.

Title: SECTIONS

Transfer of pending cases. —(1) All suits and applications, including applications under theArbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 (26 of 1996), relating to a commercial dispute of a SpecifiedValue pending in a High Court where a Commercial Division has been constituted, shall be transferred tothe Commercial Division.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Where any suit or application, including an application under the Arbitration and ConciliationAct, 1996 (26 of 1996), relating to a commercial dispute of Specified Value shall stand transferred to theCommercial Division or Commercial Court under sub-section ( 1) or sub-section ( 2), the provisions of thisAct shall apply to those procedures that were not complete at the time of transfer.

Amendments to the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 in its application to commercialdisputes. —(1) The provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908) shall, in their applicationto any suit in respect of a commercial dispute of a Specified Value, stand amended in the manner asspecified in the Schedule.

Costs. —(1) In relation to any commercial dispute, the Court, notwithstanding anythingcontained in any other law for the time being in force or Rule, has the discretion to determine:

Title: SECTIONS

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) when they are to be paid.Explanation .—For the purpose of clause ( a), the expression “costs” shall mean reasonable costsrelating to—

The Courtholds that the Plaintiff is entitled to the money decree. However, it returns a finding that the claim fordamages is frivolous and vexatious.In such circumstances the Court may impose costs on the Plaintiff, despite the Plaintiff being thesuccessful party, for having raised frivolous claims for damages.

Paragraph Text: (3) In making an order for the payment of costs, the Court shall have regard to the followingcircumstances, including—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) the conduct of the parties;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) whether a party has succeeded on part of its case, even if that party has not been whollysuccessful;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) whether the party had made a frivolous counterclaim leading to delay in the disposal ofthe case;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) whether any reasonable offer to settle is made by a party and unreasonably refused by theother party; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) whether the party had made a frivolous claim and instituted a vexatious proceedingwasting the time of the Court.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (4) The orders which the Court may make under this provision include an order that a party mustpay––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) a proportion of another party’s costs;12 (b) a stated amount in respect of another party’s costs;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) costs from or until a certain date;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) costs incurred before proceedings have begun;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) costs relating to particular steps taken in the proceedings;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (f) costs relating to a distinct part of the proceedings; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (g) interest on costs from or until a certain date.’.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 3. Amendment of section 35A. —In section 35A of the Code, sub-section ( 2) shall be omitted.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 4. Amendment of First Schedule. —In the First Schedule to the Code,––

Title: SECTIONS

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (B) in Order VI,––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) after Rule 3, the following Rule shall be inserted, namely:––“3A. Forms of pleading in Commercial Courts––In a commercial dispute, where forms ofpleadings have been prescribed under the High Court Rules or Practice Directions made forthe purposes of such commercial disputes, pleadings shall be in such forms.”;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) after Rule 15, the following Rule shall be inserted, namely:––‘‘15A. Verification of pleadings in a commercial dispute.—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in Rule 15, every pleading in a commercialdispute shall be verified by an affidavit in the manner and form prescribed in the Appendix tothis Schedule.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) An affidavit under sub-rule ( 1) above shall be signed by the party or by one of theparties to the proceedings, or by any other person on behalf of such party or parties who isproved to the satisfaction of the Court to be acquainted with the facts of the case and who isduly authorised by such party or parties.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Where a pleading is amended, the amendments must be verified in the form andmanner referred to in sub-rule ( 1) unless the Court orders otherwise.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (4) Where a pleading is not verified in the manner provided under sub-rule ( 1), the partyshall not be permitted to rely on such pleading as evidence or any of the matters set outtherein.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (5) The Court may strike out a pleading which is not verified by a Statement of Truth,namely, the affidavit set out in the Appendix to this Schedule.”;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (C) in Order VII, after Rule 2, the following Rule shall be inserted, namely:—“2A. Where interest is sought in the suit,—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (1) Where the plaintiff seeks interest, the plaint shall contain a statement to that effectalong with the details set out under sub-rules ( 2) and ( 3).13 (2) Where the plaintiff seeks interest, the plaint shall state whether the plaintiff is seekinginterest in relation to a commercial transaction within the meaning of section 34 of the Codeof Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908) and, furthermore, if the plaintiff is doing so under theterms of a contract or under an Act, in which case the Act is to be specified in the plaint; oron some other basis and shall state the basis of that.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Pleadings shall also state—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) the rate at which interest is claimed;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) the date from which it is claimed;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) the date to which it is calculated;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) the total amount of interest claimed to the date of calculation; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) the daily rate at which interest accrues after that date.”;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (D) in Order VIII,––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) in Rule 1, for the proviso, the following proviso shall be substituted, namely:––“Provided that where the defendant fails to file the written statement within the saidperiod of thirty days, he shall be allowed to file the written statement on such other day, asmay be specified by the Court, for reasons to be recorded in writing and on payment of suchcosts as the Court deems fit, but which shall not be later than one hundred twenty days fromthe date of service of summons and on expiry of one hundred twenty days from the date ofservice of summons, the defendant shall forfeit the right to file the written statement and theCourt shall not allow the written statement to be taken on record.”;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) after Rule 3, the following Rule shall be inserted, namely:––“3A. Denial by the defendant in suits before the Commercial Division of the High Courtor the Commercial Court—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (1) Denial shall be in the manner provided in sub-rules (2), (3), (4) and (5) of thisRule.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) The defendant in his written statement shall state which of the allegations in theparticulars of plaint he denies, which allegations he is unable to admit or deny, but whichhe requires the plaintiff to prove, and which allegations he admits.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Where the defendant denies an allegation of fact in a plaint, he must state hisreasons for doing so and if he intends to put forward a different version of events fromthat given by the plaintiff, he must state his own version.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (4) If the defendant disputes the jurisdiction of the Court he must state the reasons fordoing so, and if he is able, give his own statement as to which Court ought to havejurisdiction.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (5) If the defendant disputes the plaintiff’s valuation of the suit, he must state hisreasons for doing so, and if he is able, give his own statement of the value of the suit.”;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (iii) in Rule 5, in sub-rule ( 1), after the first proviso, the following proviso shall be inserted,namely: —‘‘Provided further that every allegation of fact in the plaint, if not denied in the mannerprovided under Rule 3A of this Order, shall be taken to be admitted except as against aperson under disability.”;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (iv) in Rule 10, 1*** the following proviso shall be inserted, namely:––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 1. The words “after the first proviso” omitted by Act 28 of 2018, s. 18 (w.e.f. 3-5-2018).14 “1[Provided that] no Court shall make an order to extend the time provided under Rule 1of this Order for filing of the written statement.”;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (E) for Order XI of the Code, the following Order shall be substituted, namely:—“ORDER XIDISCLOSURE, DISCOVERY AND INSPECTION OF DOCUMENTS IN SUITS BEFORE THE COMMERCIAL DIVISIONOF A HIGH COURT OR A COMMERCIAL COURT

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 1. Disclosure and discovery of documents.— (1) Plaintiff shall file a list of all documents andphotocopies of all documents, in its power, possession, control or custody, pertaining to the suit, alongwith the plaint, including:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) documents referred to and relied on by the plaintiff in the plaint;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) documents relating to any matter in question in the proceedings, in the power, possession,control or custody of the plaintiff, as on the date of filing the plaint, irrespective of whether the sameis in support of or adverse to the plaintiff’s case;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) nothing in this Rule shall apply to documents produced by plaintiffs and relevant only––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) for the cross-examination of the defendant’s witnesses, or

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) in answer to any case set up by the defendant subsequent to the filing of the plaint, or

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (iii) handed over to a witness merely to refresh his memory.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) The list of documents filed with the plaint shall specify whether the documents in the power,possession, control or custody of the plaintiff are originals, office copies or photocopies and the list shallalso set out in brief, details of parties to each document, mode of execution, issuance or receipt and line ofcustody of each document.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) The plaint shall contain a declaration on oath from the plaintiff that all documents in the power,possession, control or custody of the plaintiff, pertaining to the facts and circumstances of the proceedingsinitiated by him have been disclosed and copies thereof annexed with the plaint, and that the plaintiff doesnot have any other documents in its power, possession, control or custody.Explanation .––A declaration on oath under this sub-rule shall be contained in the Statement of Truthas set out in the Appendix.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (4) In case of urgent filings, the plaintiff may seek leave to rely on additional documents, as part ofthe above declaration on oath and subject to grant of such leave by Court, the plaintiff shall file suchadditional documents in Court, within thirty days of filing the suit, along with a declaration on oath thatthe plaintiff has produced all documents in its power, possession, control or custody, pertaining to thefacts and circumstances of the proceedings initiated by the plaintiff and that the plaintiff does not haveany other documents, in its power, possession, control or custody.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (5) The plaintiff shall not be allowed to rely on documents, which were in the plaintiff’s power,possession, control or custody and not disclosed along with plaint or within the extended period set outabove, save and except by leave of Court and such leave shall be granted only upon the plaintiffestablishing reasonable cause for non–disclosure along with the plaint.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (6) The plaint shall set out details of documents, which the plaintiff believes to be in the power,possession, control or custody of the defendant and which the plaintiff wishes to rely upon and seek leavefor production thereof by the said defendant.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (7) The defendant shall file a list of all documents and photocopies of all documents, in its power,possession, control or custody, pertaining to the suit, along with the written statement or with itscounterclaim if any, including—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) the documents referred to and relied on by the defendant in the written statement;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 1. Subs. by Act 28 of 2018, s. 18, for “Provided further that” (w.e.f. 3-5-2018).15 (b) the documents relating to any matter in question in the proceeding in the power, possession,control or custody of the defendant, irrespective of whether the same is in support of or adverse to thedefendant’s defence;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) nothing in this Rule shall apply to documents produced by the defendants and relevant only––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) for the cross-examination of the plaintiff’s witnesses,

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) in answer to any case set up by the plaintiff subsequent to the filing of the plaint, or

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (iii) handed over to a witness merely to refresh his memory.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (8) The list of documents filed with the written statement or counterclaim shall specify whether thedocuments, in the power, possession, control or custody of the defendant, are originals, office copies orphotocopies and the list shall also set out in brief, details of parties to each document being produced bythe defendant, mode of execution, issuance or receipt and line of custody of each document.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (9) The written statement or counterclaim shall contain a declaration on oath made by the deponentthat all documents in the power, possession, control or custody of the defendant, save and except for thoseset out in sub-rule ( 7) (c) (iii) pertaining to the facts and circumstances of the proceedings initiated by theplaintiff or in the counterclaim, have been disclosed and copies thereof annexed with the writtenstatement or counterclaim and that the defendant does not have in its power, possession, control orcustody, any other documents.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (10) Save and except for sub-rule ( 7) (c) (iii), defendant shall not be allowed to rely on documents,which were in the defendant’s power, possession, control or custody and not disclosed along with thewritten statement or counterclaim, save and except by leave of Court and such leave shall be granted onlyupon the defendant establishing reasonable cause for non-disclosure along with the written statement orcounterclaim.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (11) The written statement or counterclaim shall set out details of documents in the power,possession, control or custody of the plaintiff, which the defendant wishes to rely upon and which havenot been disclosed with the plaint, and call upon the plaintiff to produce the same.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (12) Duty to disclose documents, which have come to the notice of a party, shall continue till disposalof the suit.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 2. Discovery by interrogatories.— (1) In any suit the plaintiff or defendant by leave of the court maydeliver interrogatories in writing for the examination of the opposite parties or any one or more of suchparties, and such interrogatories when delivered shall have a note at the foot thereof stating which of suchinterrogatories each of such persons is required to answer:Provided that no party shall deliver more than one set of interrogatories to the same party without anorder for that purpose:Provided further that interrogatories which do not relate to any matters in question in the suit shall bedeemed irrelevant, notwithstanding that they might be admissible on the oral cross-examination of awitness.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) On an application for leave to deliver interrogatories, the particular interrogatories proposed to bedelivered shall be submitted to the court, and that court shall decide within seven days from the day offiling of the said application, in deciding upon such application, the court shall take into account anyoffer, which may be made by the party sought to be interrogated to deliver particulars, or to makeadmissions, or to produce documents relating to the matters in question, or any of them, and leave shall begiven as to such only of the interrogatories submitted as the court shall consider necessary either fordisposing fairly of the suit or for saving costs.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) In adjusting the costs of the suit inquiry shall at the instance of any party be made into thepropriety of exhibiting such interrogatories, and if it is the opinion of the taxing officer or of the court,either with or without an application for inquiry, that such interrogatories have been exhibitedunreasonably, vexatiously, or at improper length, the costs occasioned by the said interrogatories and theanswers thereto shall be paid in any event by the party in fault.16 (4) Interrogatories shall be in the form provided in Form No. 2 in Appendix C to the Code of CivilProcedure, 1908 (5 of 1908), with such variations as circumstances may require.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (5) Where any party to a suit is a corporation or a body of persons, whether incorporated or not,empowered by law to sue or be sued, whether in its own name or in the name of any officer of otherperson, any opposite party may apply for an order allowing him to deliver interrogatories to any memberor officer of such corporation or body, and an order may be made accordingly.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (6) Any objection to answering any interrogatory on the ground that it is scandalous or irrelevant ornot exhibited bona fide  for the purpose of the suit, or that the matters inquired into are not sufficientlymaterial at that stage, or on the ground of privilege or any other ground may be taken in the affidavit inanswer.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (7) Any interrogatories may be set aside on the ground that they have been exhibited unreasonably orvexatiously, or struck out on the ground that they are prolix, oppressive, unnecessary or scandalous andany application for this purpose may be made within seven days after service of the interrogatories.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (8) Interrogatories shall be answered by affidavit to be filed within ten days, or within such other timeas the court may allow.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (9) An affidavit in answer to interrogatories shall be in the form provided in Form No. 3 in AppendixC to the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908), with such variations as circumstances may require.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (10) No exceptions shall be taken to any affidavit in answer, but the sufficiency or otherwise of anysuch affidavit objected to as insufficient shall be determined by the court.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (11) Where any person interrogated omits to answer, or answers insufficiently, the party interrogatingmay apply to the court for an order requiring him to answer, or to answer further, as the case may be, andan order may be made requiring him to answer, or to answer further, either affidavit or by viva voceexamination, as the court may direct.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 3. Inspection.— (1) All parties shall complete inspection of all documents disclosed within thirtydays of the date of filing of the written statement or written statement to the counterclaim, whichever islater. The Court may extend this time limit upon application at its discretion, but not beyond thirty days inany event.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) Any party to the proceedings may seek directions from the Court, at any stage of the proceedings,for inspection or production of documents by the other party, of which inspection has been refused bysuch party or documents have not been produced despite issuance of a notice to produce.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Order in such application shall be disposed of within thirty days of filing such application,including filing replies and rejoinders (if permitted by Court) and hearing.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (4) If the above application is allowed, inspection and copies thereof shall be furnished to the partyseeking it, within five days of such order.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (5) No party shall be permitted to rely on a document, which it had failed to disclose or of whichinspection has not been given, save and except with leave of Court.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (6) The Court may impose exemplary costs against a defaulting party, who wilfully or negligentlyfailed to disclose all documents pertaining to a suit or essential for a decision therein and which are intheir power, possession, control or custody or where a Court holds that inspection or copies of anydocuments had been wrongfully or unreasonably withheld or refused.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 4. Admission and denial of documents.— (1) Each party shall submit a statement of admissions ordenials of all documents disclosed and of which inspection has been completed, within fifteen days of thecompletion of inspection or any later date as fixed by the Court.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) The statement of admissions and denials shall set out explicitly, whether such party was admittingor denying:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) correctness of contents of a document;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) existence of a document;17 (c) execution of a document;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) issuance or receipt of a document;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) custody of a document.Explanation .––A statement of admission or denial of the existence of a document made in accordancewith sub-rule ( 2) (b) shall include the admission or denial of the contents of a document.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Each party shall set out reasons for denying a document under any of the above grounds and bareand unsupported denials shall not be deemed to be denials of a document and proof of such documentsmay then be dispensed with at the discretion of the Court.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (4) Any party may however submit bare denials for third party documents of which the party denyingdoes not have any personal knowledge of, and to which the party denying is not a party to in any mannerwhatsoever.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (5) An Affidavit in support of the statement of admissions and denials shall be filed confirming thecorrectness of the contents of the statement.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (6) In the event that the Court holds that any party has unduly refused to admit a document under anyof the above criteria,–costs (including exemplary costs) for deciding on admissibility of a document maybe imposed by the Court on such party.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (7) The Court may pass orders with respect to admitted documents including for waiver of furtherproof thereon or rejection of any documents.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 5. Production of documents.— (1) Any party to a proceeding may seek or the Court may order, atany time during the pendency of any suit, production by any party or person, of such documents in thepossession or power of such party or person, relating to any matter in question in such suit.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) Notice to produce such document shall be issued in the Form provided in Form No. 7 in AppendixC to the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908).

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Any party or person to whom such notice to produce is issued shall be given not less than sevendays and not more than fifteen days to produce such document or to answer to their inability to producesuch document.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (4) The Court may draw an adverse inference against a party refusing to produce such document afterissuance of a notice to produce and where sufficient reasons for such non–production are not given andorder costs.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 6. Electronic records.— (1) In case of disclosures and inspection of Electronic Records (as defined inthe Information Technology Act, 2000 (21 of 2000)), furnishing of printouts shall be sufficientcompliance of the above provisions.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) At the discretion of the parties or where required (when parties wish to rely on audio or videocontent), copies of electronic records may be furnished in electronic form either in addition to or in lieu ofprintouts.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Where Electronic Records form part of documents disclosed, the declaration on oath to be filed bya party shall specify––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) the parties to such Electronic Record;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) the manner in which such electronic record was produced and by whom;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) the dates and time of preparation or storage or issuance or receipt of each such electronicrecord;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) the source of such electronic record and date and time when the electronic record was printed;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) in case of email ids, details of ownership, custody and access to such email ids;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (f) in case of documents stored on a computer or computer resource (including on external serversor cloud), details of ownership, custody and access to such data on the computer or computerresource;18 (g) deponent’s knowledge of contents and correctness of contents;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (h) whether the computer or computer resource used for preparing or receiving or storing suchdocument or data was functioning properly or in case of malfunction that such malfunction did notaffect the contents of the document stored;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) that the printout or copy furnished was taken from the original computer or computer resource.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (4) The parties relying on printouts or copy in electronic form, of any electronic records, shall not berequired to give inspection of electronic records, provided a declaration is made by such party that eachsuch copy, which has been produced, has been made from the original electronic record.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (5) The Court may give directions for admissibility of Electronic Records at any stage of theproceedings.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (6) Any party may seek directions from the Court and the Court may of its motion issue directions forsubmission of further proof of any electronic record including metadata or logs before admission of suchelectronic record.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 7. Certain provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 not to apply.— For avoidance of doubt,it is hereby clarified that Order XIII Rule 1, Order VII Rule 14 and Order VIII Rule 1A of the Code ofCivil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908) shall not apply to suits or applications before the Commercial Divisionsof High Court or Commercial Courts.”.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 5. Insertion of new Order XIII-A.— After Order XIII of the Code, the following Order shall beinserted, namely:—‘ORDER XIII-ASUMMARY  JUDGMENT

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 1. Scope of and classes of suits to which this Order applies.— (1) This Order sets out the procedureby which Courts may decide a claim pertaining to any Commercial Dispute without recording oralevidence.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) For the purposes of this Order, the word “claim” shall include—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) part of a claim;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) any particular question on which the claim (whether in whole or in part) depends; or

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) a counterclaim, as the case may be.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, an application for summary judgment under this Ordershall not be made in a suit in respect of any Commercial Dispute that is originally filed as a summary suitunder Order XXXVII.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 2. Stage for application for summary judgment.— An applicant may apply for summary judgmentat any time after summons has been served on the defendant:Provided that, no application for summary judgment may be made by such applicant after the Courthas framed the issues in respect of the suit.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 3. Grounds for summary judgment.— The Court may give a summary judgment against a plaintiffor defendant on a claim if it considers that––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) the plaintiff has no real prospect of succeeding on the claim or the defendant has no realprospect of successfully defending the claim, as the case may be; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) there is no other compelling reason why the claim should not be disposed of before recordingof oral evidence.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 4. Procedure.— (1) An application for summary judgment to a Court shall, in addition to any othermatters the applicant may deem relevant, include the matters set forth in sub-clauses ( a) to ( f) mentionedhereunder:—19 (a) the application must contain a statement that it is an application for summary judgment madeunder this Order;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) the application must precisely disclose all material facts and identify the point of law, if any;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) in the event the applicant seeks to rely upon any documentary evidence, the applicant must,––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) include such documentary evidence in its application, and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) identify the relevant content of such documentary evidence on which the applicant relies;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) the application must state the reason why there are no real prospects of succeeding on theclaim or defending the claim, as the case may be;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) the application must state what relief the applicant is seeking and briefly state the grounds forseeking such relief.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) Where a hearing for summary judgment is fixed, the respondent must be given at least thirty days’notice of:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) the date fixed for the hearing; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) the claim that is proposed to be decided by the Court at such hearing.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) The respondent may, within thirty days of the receipt of notice of application of summaryjudgment or notice of hearing (whichever is earlier), file a reply addressing the matters set forth in clauses

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) to ( f) mentioned hereunder in addition to any other matters that the respondent may deem relevant:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) the reply must precisely––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) disclose all material facts;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) identify the point of law, if any; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (iii) state the reasons why the relief sought by the applicant should not be granted;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) in the event the respondent seeks to rely upon any documentary evidence in its reply, therespondent must—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) include such documentary evidence in its reply; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) identify the relevant content of such documentary evidence on which the respondentrelies;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) the reply must state the reason why there are real prospects of succeeding on the claim ordefending the claim, as the case may be;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) the reply must concisely state the issues that should be framed for trial;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) the reply must identify what further evidence shall be brought on record at trial that could notbe brought on record at the stage of summary judgment; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (f) the reply must state why, in light of the evidence or material on record if any, the Court shouldnot proceed to summary judgment.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 5. Evidence for hearing of summary judgment.— (1) Notwithstanding anything in this Order, if therespondent in an application for summary judgment wishes to rely on additional documentary evidenceduring the hearing, the respondent must:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) file such documentary evidence; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) serve copies of such documentary evidence on every other party to the application at leastfifteen days prior to the date of the hearing.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) Notwithstanding anything in this Order, if the applicant for summary judgment wishes to rely ondocumentary evidence in reply to the defendant’s documentary evidence, the applicant must:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) file such documentary evidence in reply; and20 (b) serve a copy of such documentary evidence on the respondent at least five days prior to thedate of the hearing.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, sub-rules ( 1) and ( 2) shall not require documentaryevidence to be:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) filed if such documentary evidence has already been filed; or

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) served on a party on whom it has already been served.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 6. Orders that may be made by Court.— (1) On an application made under this Order, the Courtmay make such orders that it may deem fit in its discretion including the following:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) judgment on the claim;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) conditional order in accordance with Rule 7 mentioned hereunder;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) dismissing the application;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) dismissing part of the claim and a judgment on part of the claim that is not dismissed;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) striking out the pleadings (whether in whole or in part); or

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (f) further directions to proceed for case management under Order XV-A.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) Where the Court makes any of the orders as set forth in sub-rule ( 1) (a) to ( f), the Court shallrecord its reasons for making such order.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 7. Conditional order.— (1) Where it appears to the Court that it is possible that a claim or defencemay succeed but it is improbable that it shall do so, the Court may make a conditional order as set forth inRule 6 ( 1) (b).

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) Where the Court makes a conditional order, it may:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) make it subject to all or any of the following conditions:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) require a party to deposit a sum of money in the Court;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) require a party to take a specified step in relation to the claim or defence, as the case maybe;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (iii) require a party, as the case may be, to give such security or provide such surety forrestitution of costs as the Court deems fit and proper;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (iv) impose such other conditions, including providing security for restitution of losses thatany party is likely to suffer during the pendency of the suit, as the Court may deem fit in itsdiscretion; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) specify the consequences of the failure to comply with the conditional order, includingpassing a judgment against the party that have not complied with the conditional order.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 8. Power to impose costs.— The Court may make an order for payment of costs in an application forsummary judgment in accordance with the provisions of sections 35 and 35A of the Code.’.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 6. Omission of Order XV.— Order XV of the Code shall be omitted.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 7. Insertion of Order XV-A.— 7. After Order XV of the Code, the following Order shall be inserted,namely:—“ORDER XVACASE MANAGEMENT HEARING

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 1. First Case Management Hearing.— The Court shall hold the first Case Management Hearing, notlater than four weeks from the date of filing of affidavit of admission or denial of documents by all partiesto the suit.21 2. Orders to be passed in a Case Management Hearing.— In a Case Management Hearing, afterhearing the parties, and once it finds that there are issues of fact and law which require to be tried, theCourt may pass an order––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) framing the issues between the parties in accordance with Order XIV of the Code of CivilProcedure, 1908 (5 of 1908) after examining pleadings, documents and documents produced before it,and on examination conducted by the Court under Rule 2 of Order X, if required;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) listing witnesses to be examined by the parties;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) fixing the date by which affidavit of evidence to be filed by parties;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) fixing the date on which evidence of the witnesses of the parties to be recorded;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) fixing the date by which written arguments are to be filed before the Court by the parties;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (f) fixing the date on which oral arguments are to be heard by the Court; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (g) setting time limits for parties and their advocates to address oral arguments.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 3. Time limit for the completion of a trial.— In fixing dates or setting time limits for the purposes ofRule 2 of this Order, the Court shall ensure that the arguments are closed not later than six months fromthe date of the first Case Management Hearing.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 4. Recording of oral evidence on a day-to-day basis.— The Court shall, as far as possible, ensurethat the recording of evidence shall be carried on, on a day-to-day basis until the cross-examination of allthe witnesses is complete.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 5. Case Management Hearings during a trial.— The Court may, if necessary, also hold CaseManagement Hearings anytime during the trial to issue appropriate orders so as to ensure adherence bythe parties to the dates fixed under Rule 2 and facilitate speedy disposal of the suit.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 6. Powers of the Court in a Case Management Hearing.— (1) In any Case Management Hearingheld under this Order, the Court shall have the power to—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) prior to the framing of issues, hear and decide any pending application filed by the partiesunder Order XIII-A;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) direct parties to file compilations of documents or pleadings relevant and necessary forframing issues;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) extend or shorten the time for compliance with any practice, direction or Court order if it findssufficient reason to do so;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) adjourn or bring forward a hearing if it finds sufficient reason to do so;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) direct a party to attend the Court for the purposes of examination under Rule 2 of Order X;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (f) consolidate proceedings;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (g) strike off the name of any witness or evidence that it deems irrelevant to the issues framed;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (h) direct a separate trial of any issue;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) decide the order in which issues are to be tried;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (j) exclude an issue from consideration;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (k) dismiss or give judgment on a claim after a decision on a preliminary issue;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (l) direct that evidence be recorded by a Commission where necessary in accordance with OrderXXVI;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (m) reject any affidavit of evidence filed by the parties for containing irrelevant, inadmissible orargumentative material;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (n) strike off any parts of the affidavit of evidence filed by the parties containing irrelevant,inadmissible or argumentative material;22 (o) delegate the recording of evidence to such authority appointed by the Court for this purpose;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (p) pass any order relating to the monitoring of recording the evidence by a commission or anyother authority;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (q) order any party to file and exchange a costs budget;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (r) issue directions or pass any order for the purpose of managing the case and furthering theoverriding objective of ensuring the efficient disposal of the suit.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) When the Court passes an order in exercise of its powers under this Order, it may—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) make it subject to conditions, including a condition to pay a sum of money into Court; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) specify the consequence of failure to comply with the order or a condition.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3) While fixing the date for a Case Management Hearing, the Court may direct that the parties alsobe present for such Case Management Hearing, if it is of the view that there is a possibility of settlementbetween the parties.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 7. Adjournment of Case Management Hearing.— (1) The Court shall not adjourn the CaseManagement Hearing for the sole reason that the advocate appearing on behalf of a party is not present:Provided that an adjournment of the hearing is sought in advance by moving an application, the Courtmay adjourn the hearing to another date upon the payment of such costs as the Court deems fit, by theparty moving such application.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Rule, if the Court is satisfied that there is a justifiedreason for the absence of the advocate, it may adjourn the hearing to another date upon such terms andconditions it deems fit.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 8. Consequences of non-compliance with orders.— Where any party fails to comply with the orderof the Court passed in a Case Management Hearing, the Court shall have the power to—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) condone such non-compliance by payment of costs to the Court;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) foreclose the non-compliant party’s right to file affidavits, conduct cross-examination ofwitnesses, file written submissions, address oral arguments or make further arguments in the trial, asthe case may be, or

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) dismiss the plaint or allow the suit where such non-compliance is wilful, repeated and theimposition of costs is not adequate to ensure compliance.”.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 8. Amendment of Order XVIII.— In Order XVIII of the Code, in Rule 2, for sub-rules ( 3A), (3B),

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3C), (3D), (3E) and ( 3F), the following shall be substituted, namely:––“(3A) A party shall, within four weeks prior to commencing the oral arguments, submit conciselyand under distinct headings written arguments in support of his case to the Court and such writtenarguments shall form part of the record.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3B) The written arguments shall clearly indicate the provisions of the laws being cited in supportof the arguments and the citations of judgments being relied upon by the party and include copies ofsuch judgments being relied upon by the party.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3C) A copy of such written arguments shall be furnished simultaneously to the opposite party.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3D) The Court may, if it deems fit, after the conclusion of arguments, permit the parties to filerevised written arguments within a period of not more than one week after the date of conclusion ofarguments.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3E) No adjournment shall be granted for the purpose of filing the written arguments unless theCourt, for reasons to be recorded in writing, considers it necessary to grant such adjournment.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (3F) It shall be open for the Court to limit the time for oral submissions having regard to thenature and complexity of the matter.”.23 9. Amendment of Order XVIII.— In Order XVIII of the Code, in Rule 4, after sub-rule ( 1), thefollowing sub-rules shall be inserted, namely:––‘‘(1A) The affidavits of evidence of all witnesses whose evidence is proposed to be led by a partyshall be filed simultaneously by that party at the time directed in the first Case Management Hearing.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (1B) A party shall not lead additional evidence by the affidavit of any witness (including of awitness who has already filed an affidavit) unless sufficient cause is made out in an application forthat purpose and an order, giving reasons, permitting such additional affidavit is passed by the Court.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (1C) A party shall however have the right to withdraw any of the affidavits so filed at any timeprior to commencement of cross-examination of that witness, without any adverse inference beingdrawn based on such withdrawal:Provided that any other party shall be entitled to tender as evidence and rely upon any admissionmade in such withdrawn affidavit.”.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 10. Amendment to Order XIX.— In Order XIX of the Code, after Rule 3, the following Rules shallbe inserted, namely:––“4. Court may control evidence.— (1) The Court may, by directions, regulate the evidence as toissues on which it requires evidence and the manner in which such evidence may be placed before theCourt.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (2) The Court may, in its discretion and for reasons to be recorded in writing, exclude evidencethat would otherwise be produced by the parties.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 5. Redacting or rejecting evidence.— A Court may, in its discretion, for reasons to be recordedin writing––

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) redact or order the redaction of such portions of the affidavit of examination-in-chief as donot, in its view, constitute evidence; or

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) return or reject an affidavit of examination-in-chief as not constituting admissibleevidence.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 6. Format and guidelines of affidavit of evidence.— An affidavit must comply with the formand requirements set forth below:—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (a) such affidavit should be confined to, and should follow the chronological sequence of, thedates and events that are relevant for proving any fact or any other matter dealt with;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (b) where the Court is of the view that an affidavit is a mere reproduction of the pleadings, orcontains the legal grounds of any party’s case, the Court may, by order, strike out the affidavit orsuch parts of the affidavit, as it deems fit and proper;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (c) each paragraph of an affidavit should, as far as possible, be confined to a distinct portionof the subject;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (d) an affidavit shall state—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) which of the statements in it are made from the deponent’s own knowledge and whichare matters of information or belief; and

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) the source for any matters of information or belief;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (e) an affidavit should—

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (i) have the pages numbered consecutively as a separate document (or as one of severaldocuments contained in a file);

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (ii) be divided into numbered paragraphs;

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: (iii) have all numbers, including dates, expressed in figures; and24 (iv) if any of the documents referred to in the body of the affidavit are annexed to theaffidavit or any other pleadings, give the annexures and page numbers of such documents thatare relied upon.”.

Title: SECTIONS
Paragraph Text: 11. Amendment of Order XX.— In Order XX of the Code, for Rule 1, the following Rule shall besubstituted, namely:––“(1) The 1[Commercial Court, Commercial Appellate Court], Commercial Division, orCommercial Appellate Division, as the case may be, shall, within ninety days of the conclusion ofarguments, pronounce judgment and copies thereof shall be issued to all the parties to the disputethrough electronic mail or otherwise.”.2[12.
